docs.lead_paragraph: Even as New York has embarked on a campaign to increase access to the federal benefits, many who are already enrolled in the program either lose them or struggle to renew them.

headline.main: Navigating a Bureaucratic Maze to Renew Food Stamp Benefits
headline.print_headline: Navigating Bureaucratic Maze in the City to Renew Food Stamp Benefits

docs.abstract: New York City has launched effort to increase access to food stamps, but many people who need the benefits say they go through frustrating and overly bureaucratic process to renew them; some lose food stamp benefits in resulting confusion.
docs.snippet: Even as New York has embarked on a campaign to increase access to the federal benefits, many who are already enrolled in the program either lose them or struggle to renew them.

docs.lead_paragraph: Move over sweet and salty: Researchers say we have a distinct and basic taste for fat, too.

headline.main: Fat Sense: Scientists Show We Have a Distinct Taste for Fat
headline.print_headline: Fat Sense: Scientists Show We Have a Distinct Taste for Fat

docs.snippet: Move over sweet and salty: Researchers say we have a distinct and basic taste for fat, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: SHILS--Maurice Edward, M.D. FACP, ScD. December 31, 1914 - June 29, 2015. Husband of Betty Bell Shils of Mobile, Alabama; father of Jonathan Shils of Atlanta, Georgia; and Loraine Shils (David) Hammack of Shaker Heights, Ohio; with his wife of almost 50 years, Cylia Finkel Shils (deceased); grandfather of Elizabeth (Michael Ulchak) Hammack, Peter (Beth) Hammack and Sarah (Bret) Kovacs and great grandfather of four. Professor Emeritus of Medicine, Cornell Medical College, retired Attending Physician and Director of Clinical Nutrition, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; retired Executive Secretary, Committee on Public Health of New York Academy of Medicine; retired Adjunct Professor, Wake Forest School of Medicine; senior editor of Modern Nutrition in Health and Disease, 7-10th editions. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: Even those with high ambitions are more likely than their predecessors to plan to scale back at work at certain times.

headline.main: More Than Their Mothers, Young Women Plan Career Pauses
headline.print_headline: Increasingly, Young Women Plan Career Pauses

docs.abstract: The Upshot; growing body of survey data shows that educated, working women in millenial generation, from ages 18 to early 30s, are more likely than previous generations to plan on scaling back work priorities to focus on family at different times, and vice versa.
docs.snippet: Even those with high ambitions are more likely than their predecessors to plan to scale back at work at certain times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, July 22, 2015.
docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, July 22, 2015.
